ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

ANG MO KIO NEW TOWN (AVENUES 1, 3 and 6)
(Bus-bays and bus shelters)


    1. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for National Development and Communications whether it is proposed to construct bus-bays and bus shelters along Avenues 1, 3 and 6, Ang Mo Kio, and to provide a bus shelter at the temporary bus terminus at Ang Mo Kio New Town.

Column: 1010



    The Senior Minister of State for National Development (Dr Tan Eng Liang) (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Sir, there are already six bus-bays and two bus shelters along Avenue 3 and Avenue 6 Ang Mo Kio. In addition, the Public Works Department will be constructing four bus shelters along Avenue 1 and Avenue 3 this year.

    The Public Works Department is also looking into the possibility of providing a temporary bus shelter at the temporary bus terminus at Ang Mo Kio New Town.

    2. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for National Development and

Communications what sort of recreational facilities are being planned on the vacant site in front of Block 214, Avenue 3, Ang Mo Kio, and when they will be ready.

    Dr Tan Eng Liang (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Sir, there is a proposal to turn the vacant site in front of Block 214, Avenue 3, Ang Mo Kio, into an open field for outdoor games. The construction of the open field is expected to be completed by the middle of this year.

    Mr Yeo Toon Chia (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, in addition to the playing field to be constructed at the vacant land fronting Block 214, is there any plan to build a sports complex in the Ang Mo Kio constituency?

    Dr Tan Eng Liang: Sir, the vacant land referred to by the Member for Ang Mo Kio is actually in Neighbourhood II of Ang Mo Kio New Town. However, the HDB will be looking into the construction of a sports complex in Neighbourhood III. The area for this sports complex is under clearance at the moment, and because it is heavily encumbered it will take some time for this project to be completed. However, it is expected that tenders will probably be invited sometime towards the end of this year, and it is hoped that this sports complex would be ready by 1980.

ANG MO KIO NEW TOWN
(Industrial development)


    3. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for National Development and Communications if he will enlighten the House on the different types of industries planned for the industrial site in Ang Mo Kio New Town and when construction is expected to be completed; and whether the Housing and Development Board will liaise with the Economic Development Board on the possibility of setting up factories in the area.

Column: 1012



    Dr Tan Eng Liang (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Sir, approximately 100 hectares of land has been set aside for industrial development in Ang Mo Kio New Town. Generally, the type of industries to be set up should not pose any pollution problem and should provide job opportunities for the residents in Ang Mo Kio New Town.

    To cater for the small industries, terrace factories for metal workshops, carpentry workshops and engineering workshops will be constructed in stages from this year 1977 to 1979. Some vacant sites will also be set aside for leasing to light industries. The specific types of industries will depend on the recommendation of the Economic Development Board and the acceptance of the various relevant Authorities, such as Anti-Pollution Unit, Public Health Department and Factory Inspectorate.

    The Housing and Development Board is liaising closely with the Economic Development Board on the development of these industrial sites.

    Mr Ivan Baptist (Potong Pasir): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head N be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead ADA 1101*. (* The same amendment also stood in the name of Dr Ong Leong Boon.)

    In 1975 13,966 accidents were reported to the Workmen's Compensation Section. Of these, 3,278 were reported under the new Act which came into force in that year. When the Workmen's Compensation Act of 1971 was repealed and the 1975 Act came into being, among other things, the new Act included industrial dermatitis and noise-induced deafness as compensable diseases.

Column: 1013

This was in line with the Ministry's policy to continue in its effort to improve the health and welfare of workers and to bring the legislation in line with the modern working environment - that utilises chemicals and other irritants that can cause serious skin ailments if workers are not protected against them through barrier creams or appropriate gloves. In addition the high noise levels in certain manufacturing sectors could probably deafen workers if they are not adequately protected with ear protection.

    Since the introduction of this legislation, Sir, I believe that some cases of industrial dermatitis and noise-induced deafness must have been compensated. The latest Ministry of Labour annual report. 1975, does not carry any figures of compensation paid out for these two compensable diseases. Perhaps it is too early for such cases to have emerged, as the law was only then three months' old. But as the 1976 annual report is not available (I do not know whether it is still being printed or being prepared), I would like to know the latest figures of compensation paid out and the number of cases concerned, separately, in respect of these two diseases, since they were included in the Schedule to the Workmen's Compensation Act as compensable diseases.

    Could the Minister also enlighten the House whether these workers obtained alternative employment or are still employed in the same establishment where they contracted the diseases? If they are still employed by the same employer, are they in the same jobs as they were prior to contracting these diseases?

    Dr Ong Leong Boon (Kim Seng): Sir, I am raising the question in relation to the workings of the Workmen's Compensation Act. As we know, the patients, i.e, the workers, are submitted to medical examination and the extent of permanent or temporary incapacity is then certified.

    I have here a copy of the Workmen's Compensation Guide and a copy of the medical report (standard format) upon which doctors have to fill in the particulars. I am

Column: 1014

suggesting here that the present format for the operation of the Workmen's Compensation Act is not sufficient and does not give a clear-cut indication as to the workings of the Workmen's Compensation Act. It is not my intention to question the quantum of award for workmen's compensation. Neither am I questioning the guidelines for the award for specific loss of limb or part of it, although I have my own reservation on some of these guidelines. I am referring, in particular, to this format which the certifying doctor will have to fill in, and this can be improved if it could be better tabulated in terms of temporary or permanent loss. On top of this, in the interest of the injured person, a form of Compensation Medical Board should be established. This would then allow for more equitable, more expert and fairer medical certification for injuries sustained or diseases contracted during employment. We know at the present moment, all and sundry among the medical profession attend to workmen's compensation. This ranges from expert professors and consultants to very young doctors who have barely one year's medical experience. I could quote examples where a workman who deserved only 5% compensation award was granted 60%. On the other hand the injured person who deserved 30% was given just 5% compensation. Therefore, in the interest of the injured person, may I kindly suggest that a Workmen's Compensation Board be established.

    There are insufficient guidelines provided for other elements like emotional or ethnic characteristics of the injured person. This is important because very often if an injured person knows how to play up certain residual symptoms, he or she tends to get away with more awards. I therefore suggest that some guidelines in this direction be provided.

    One other matter, which we are all familiar with, is that the injured resort to cultural medicinal practitioners. Very often we do face this problem and as a result of mismanagement the result of treatment is appalling, and yet the same person comes and expects to be compensated for this. I

Column: 1015

think some guidelines too should be provided in this direction. I am making this request, bearing in mind the interest of the injured person and in the name affair play.

    The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Fong Sip Chee): Sir, may I first deal with the points raised by the hon. Member for Potong Pasir. Briefly, the Member is concerned with two matters, that is, industrial dermatitis and noise-induced deafness. For the benefit of Members of the House, industrial dermatitis simply means a skin disease. So I prefer to use this term from now on instead of using the technical term. Industrial dermatitis and noise-induced deafness were added to the list of compensable occupational diseases under the Workmen's Compensation Act, 1975. It came into operation on the 1st October of that year.

2.45 p.m.

    On skin diseases, the Ministry has not conducted any survey recently but the figures of notification for the past two years for these two diseases are available, and for the information of Members they are as follows.

    There were 9 cases of skin diseases in 1975 and 187 in 1976. For noise-induced deafness, no case was registered in 1975 and 912 cases were detected in 1976. Hon. Members should not be alarmed by this figure as I will explain further on this. 870 of these were early cases and only 42 cases were what we regard as proper cases. So do not be alarmed with the high figure. The reason for the increase in the number of skin diseases confirmed in 1976 was due to the compulsory reporting of these cases by medical practitioners under the law. Prior to that, there was no requirement. So there might be cases that did not come to the attention of the Ministry of Labour. Most of these skin diseases were due to the handling of engineering oil or some raw materials, about 56.7% of them resulted from the handling of engineering oil; 10.7% from handling of resins; 8.6% due to solvents; another 8.6% due to handling of fibreglass; 2.1% on cement; 2.1% on paint; and the others about 11.2%

Column: 1016



    A programme of prevention has been developed and the main task of this programme was the education of workers to minimise skin contact with the irritating and allergic substances through the use of proper protective covering, such as protective clothings, aprons, gloves, face shields and other barrier cream which the Member for Potong Pasir mentioned earlier. To launch this programme the Ministry printed and distributed 3,500 copies of a pamphlet on industrial skin diseases in two languages, namely, Chinese and English, and 1,800 copies of this pamphlet have been distributed to the various industries with known risks of industrial skin diseases, such as the electronic factories, woodworking where they deal with a certain kind of adhesive gum, cement, paint and other factories.

    Members are probably aware that industrial skin diseases are by and large a transient kind of disease. They are temporary in the sense that the condition may last for only a few days to a few weeks and very rarely result in residual disability. Once the worker is detected and is removed from the contact of the offending substance or is isolated from the environment, his condition invariably improves.

    The question of the great increase of 912 cases of noise-induced deafness reported was largely due to the introduction of the mobile audiometric screening programme for the noisy industries. It was started in May 1977. The screening programme covered a total of 1,731 employees from 33 shipyards and 942 employees from 20 other noisy industries, such as the bottling, cement and concrete pipe-manufacturing factories, etc. By the end of 1976, a total of 912 noise-induced deafness cases were detected. The majority of these cases were in the early stages and only a small number of 42 cases were severe enough to attract workmen's compensation.

    The Ministry has developed a hearing conservation programme as a preventive measure to control noise-induced deafness. The main emphasis of this hearing conservation programme, which has been widely publicised, is to educate and persuade

Column: 1017

workers to put on hearing protectors while at work. Noise control is carried out only when it is considered technically and economically feasible by the factories. Pamphlets on noise-induced deafness in three languages. Chinese. English and Malay, and also a booklet on the hearing conservation programme have been published and distributed free of charge to those industries with the risk of hearing loss. About 3,000 of the pamphlets have been distributed to noisy factories, such as shipyards, textiles, metal and other manufacturing establishments. Over 600 copies of the hearing conservation programme booklets have been distributed to shipyards, metal can manufacturing. woodworking, textile and other factories.

    At this stage. I might wish to draw a line that the hearing conservation programme is distinct from noise pollution control. In the United States, there were arguments as to whether 90 decibels should be the accepted norm instead of 85 decibels. So there was a research trying to reduce 90 decibels down to 85 decibels and they discovered that for every point reduced from 90 to 85 decibels it would cost the industry somewhere around US$2 billion. I do not think Singapore has reached that stage to mount that noise pollution control which is quite distinct from the hearing conservation programme. So we are launching on a more practical approach to this problem rather than throw the problem out of its proportion.

    May I now deal with the hon. Member for Kim Seng. The Workmen's Compensation Act provides sufficient basis and guidelines for the award of loss of earning capacity in respect of permanent incapacity suffered by our workmen as a result of injuries while at work. The First Schedule to the Act specifies the percentage to be awarded for the loss of use of the various members of the body. The listing in the Schedule is very comprehensive and covers even the loss of parts of a member, that is, for example, the loss of phalanx. There is therefore no difficulty for the doctor to make an award for such injuries.

    However, I agree with the Member that there are certain types of injuries, such as those involving fractures or internal injury which cannot be quite easily determined as to the loss of capacity. It may be possible to have differing medical assessments on the loss of use of the part concerned. Where such differences of opinion occur, although very rarely, it is the practice of the Ministry to refer the injured workman for a final assessment by a specialist. The Ministry is aware of the need for uniformity in medical assessment for these types of injuries. It is, in fact, taking steps to seek the assistance of the Ministry of Health to draw up guidelines for doctors to follow on the same basis as those listed on the First Schedule of the Act.

    As to whether or not we should constitute a board or panel. I think the objective is the same. Rather than set up another administrative barrier, which may cause delay to compensation being awarded, I think the main objective is to ensure uniformity. I will bear in mind the Member's suggestion, which is a good one. We will look into that.

    In the case of an injured workman who refuses treatment, the Workmen's Compensation Act provides for suspension of his right to compensation until he offers himself for a medical examination. The hon. Member has mentioned that there are a few cases where the injured worker, having submitted himself for treatment, subsequently stopped medication and sought the treatment of physicians of traditional methods who are registered medical.

Column: 1019

practitioners. I must say that this is a dangerous practice and the injury may be aggravated, and if confirmed by the doctor treating him, might result in legal complication and the objection by the insurance company on the quantum of the final compensation. I would appreciate that if such cases do occur the doctor treating the worker should refer the case to us. So far, there are very, very few such cases, fortunately.

    With regard to the other irregularity mentioned by the Member about the differences in the sensitivity to pain experienced by different workers, with different cultural backgrounds, some workers cannot bear to see the sight of an injection needle, it must be pointed out that workmen's compensation, unlike the common law, does not take into consideration such factors. The compensation awarded under the Act is based solely on the objective yardstick of the loss of earning capacity. Subjective factors such as pain and suffering should not be included in the assessment of compensation to be paid under the Act.

    I hope I have answered the questions raised by the hon. Members.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Sir, one point of clarification. The Senior Parliamentary Secretary mentioned that the booklet was published in three languages. I want to know what are the languages and whether Tamil is included.

    Mr Fong Sip Chee: I am very sorry, Sir. The three languages are English, Chinese and Malay. Unfortunately, we left out Tamil because we believe most of the Tamil workers do read English. And for reasons of cost and coverage, we believe the three languages would suffice to cover the entire workforce. If there is a need in some particular industry where Tamil workers are in the majority, we will produce future booklets with Tamil in mind.

    Mr Ivan Baptist: Sir, three points of clarification. First, the Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour stated

that the noise level of 90 decibels was considered in the United States and after some discussion they decided not to belabour this particular problem due to its cost. But I do believe that noise levels are not the only ones to be considered but also exposure time. Maybe the Senior Parliamentary Secretary had just missed It out inadvertently. I believe it is six hours.

    On the second point with regard to noise-induced deafness, the quantum of compensation paid out has not been answered by the Parliamentary Secretary. He mentioned about 2,000-plus workers were screened by the audiometric testing facilities at the Ministry. I believe there are 24,000 workers in about 400 factories with high noise levels. How does the Ministry intend to cover all these. And when they do so, will the levels of noise-induced deafness and the quantum of compensation shoot up to a fantastic level that could frighten us?

3.00 p.m.

In fact, the problem in the United States has grown beyond the question of protecting the workers. As I have said, there is a difference between noise pollution control and hearing conservation. We are adopting hearing conservation but not noise pollution control. In the United States this problem has grown far beyond the scope of industrial health. It has become a political issue where even a politician running for a mayor -

    Sir, under this subhead I would like to touch upon industrial accidents. Although this question has been raised many a time in the past in this House, and the Ministry has been urged to take more effective measures to reduce its occurrence, industrial accidents continue to recur now and then. According to statistics, there were 4,252 cases of industrial accidents in 1976 and in 1975 there were 3,827 showing an increase of 425 cases. In 1975 there were 67 fatal cases, whereas in 1976 there were 62 cases, showing a slight decrease. Just about a week ago there was a serious industrial accident at the Senoko Power Plant in Sembawang which resulted in three deaths and three wounded.

    What is worth mentioning is that among industrial accident figures for the building construction industry, those relating to HDB worksites rate quite a high proportion. According to Volume 2, No. 8 of Lao gong zhi shi (    ) the Chinese equivalent of the "New Worker" published by the Educational Publications Bureau, in 1975 there were 651 industrial accidents in building sites, of which 155 cases involved

Column: 1023

the HDB, and from January to July 1977 there were 177 accidents involving HDB worksites, among which there were 16 fatality cases. This shows that there are still many shortcomings and loopholes in the HDB worksite safety measures. There should be more stringent control and supervision. The supervisory or managerial officers should have been severely reprimanded, because it is not a small matter that so many precious lives have been lost and so many able bodied persons have been seriously incapacitated. Had there been better safety precautions taken, these unnecessary losses would have been avoided.

    In the field of safety precautions. I remember that some two years ago the Institute of Occupational Health and Safety was set up to look into industrial health and safety and related matters. Now after two years of research they must have some valuable and concrete proposals to make. I would like to know what are the results of the last two years and what are their recommendations. When will these recommendations be put into effect to reduce industrial accidents.

    Sir, other than the shipbuilding industry which shows a decreasing number of accident cases, there are still many serious accidents involving other industries, particularly the building construction industry. There were 698 cases last year. This is an area which we should pay attention to. Since we have various industrial safety provisions, they should be stringently carried out.

    The Minister explained that there was a shortage of inspectors and the funds allocated by the Finance Ministry were not sufficient. I am quite in sympathy with the Minister. However. I feel that this is a matter of life and death. It is not a small matter to be treated lightly. The Ministry concerned should try its best to get more funds from the Finance Ministry in order to employ more inspectors. The Inspectorate now has 77 permanent officers, including inspectors, in relation to tens of thousands of factories. I feel the number is too small. More inspectors

Column: 1024

should be recruited, in order to ensure better industrial safety.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Mr Speaker, Sir, I fully support the Member for Sembawang. He has produced facts and figures which I want to talk about further.

    What safety measures are being introduced in factories, worksites and shipyards? There does not seem to be a reduction in the number of fatal cases at these places. There seems to be too much complacency on the part of the employers and the Labour Ministry. During the last one year, there have been a number of fatal accident cases in shipyards and worksites. It looks as though life is cheap in these places, very cheap. Lately, the accident involving a mobile crane at the Senoko Power Station worksite could be a typical example of a possible lack of proper supervision, and the overall careless attitude to life at worksites. Human life is cheap' Despite safety campaigns, which are sporadic at the most, there seems to be no reduction in accidents involving the loss of life and limb at shipyards, worksites and factories. The safety units and factory inspectorate must really expand and wake up!

    There is a shortage of inspectors and they cannot sufficiently enforce safety measures at the worksites. Everywhere buildings are coming up, shipyards and other worksites. There are not enough inspectors. The Labour Ministry should increase the Inspectorate staff. Later we will then see whether there are any more accidents.

    Mr Fong Sip Chee: Mr Speaker, Sir, in fact the shortest answer to these two proposals is yes, we welcome more staff. Definitely it will do us a whole world of good.

    But before I deal with the specific points raised by both the Member for Anson and the Member for Sembawang, perhaps I might take this opportunity to enlighten the two Members on certain statistical information which they might have read from the Press from time to time and on which they might have based their observations. The Member for Sembawang has quoted the correct

Column: 1025

statistics. Could the Member for Potong Pasir, please take note? This is very important, as I will explain now.

    The state of industrial health and safety cannot be measured merely on simple statistics on the number of cases and the number of fatalities alone. There are other factors which must be taken into consideration in order to obtain a proper assessment of the real situation. A detailed explanation might be too academic for the purposes of discussion in this House. Therefore, I think it would suffice to state that other factors, such as the severity rate, frequency rate, number of man-hours worked, number of workers and so on, are all important considerations.

3.15 p.m.

    The random quoting of statistics in the mass media appears to have swayed the views of some hon. Members as well as members of the public; hence the observation that the state of industrial health and safety in the Republic appears to have got out of hand. I have previously explained in this House that there is a difference between the statistics of the workmen's compensation figures and the Factory Inspectorate figures.
